result_equations.equation: d vec B = (mu_0)/(4 pi) (I d vec l times hat r)/(r^2)
vec B = (mu_0 I)/(4 pi) oint (d vec l times hat r)/(r^2)

explanation: The Biot-Savart law calculates the magnetic field produced by a steady current. It states that the magnetic field contribution from a current element is proportional to the current, the length element, and inversely proportional to the square of the distance. This law is fundamental for calculating magnetic fields from arbitrary current distributions.

definitions.definition: Magnetic field contribution from current element.
Unit vector from current element to field point.
Distance from current element to field point.

assumptions: Maxwell's equations apply for static magnetic fields.
The current flows in thin wires (line current approximation).

derivation.description: Start with Ampère's law in differential form from Maxwell's equations.
derivation.equation: nabla times vec B = mu_0 vec J

derivation.description: Use the fact that magnetic field is divergence-free (no magnetic monopoles).
Solve the magnetic field equations using Green's function method.
derivation.equation: vec B(vec r) = (mu_0)/(4 pi) int (vec J(vec r') times (vec r - vec r'))/|vec r - vec r'|^3 d^3 r'

derivation.description: Express current density in terms of line current for thin wires.
derivation.equation: vec J d^3 r' = I d vec l

derivation.description: Transform volume integral to line integral along the current path.
derivation.equation: vec B(vec r) = (mu_0 I)/(4 pi) oint (d vec l times (vec r - vec r'))/|vec r - vec r'|^3

derivation.description: Define unit vector from source to field point.
derivation.equation: hat r = (vec r - vec r')/|vec r - vec r'|

derivation.description: Obtain the Biot-Savart law for the magnetic field contribution.
derivation.equation: d vec B = (mu_0)/(4 pi) (I d vec l times hat r)/(r^2)
